statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Colorado State 72, Colorado 69
article.story: BOULDER, Colo. (AP) -- Neither history nor Colorado's fullcourt press rattled the Colorado State Rams enough for them to fritter away their first win in Boulder in nearly half a century. They withstood a furious comeback in the last three minutes to prevail 72-69 Saturday night for their first win on Colorado's campus since Dec. 2, 1957. "I wasn't born yet," said CSU coach Dale Layer, who was born in 1958. "None of us here were around the last time we won in Boulder." Jason Smith had 15 points and 16 rebounds for the Rams (7-2), who led by 15 with three minutes to go only to see their lead dwindle to 71-69 on Richard Roby's breakaway basket with 22 seconds left. "It was blue knuckle time," Smith said. "We knew we had to dig deep and find a way. We never doubted that we could. The end was all determination. We knew we couldn't stay down for long." Tim Denson sank one of two free throws with 18 seconds remaining, and Roby, who led the Buffs with 20 points but missed 10-of-15 shots from the floor, rushed a 3-pointer that was long with 10 seconds left. The Rams got the ball out of bounds and this time they didn't get trapped in the backcourt, completing a series of impressive passes before dribbling out the clock. "We got a little tentative, they got aggressive and sometimes that's what happens," Layer said. "I think it was great to win a game like this. It will help us down the road." Smith said having to sweat it out made the win that much sweeter, too. "It wouldn't have meant as much if we hadn't had to work so hard for it," he said. Colorado State led 55-39 on Smith's dunk with 11:56 left and still appeared comfortably in front at 69-54 with three minutes remaining. But the Rams' runaway turned into a dogfight as the Buffs went to a fullcourt press and began to chip away. "We just pulled together as a team and said it wasn't over," Roby said. "And we got it to single digits and felt like we had a chance to win." The Buffs (3-6), who are off to their worst start since 1987-88, fell to 1-4 against Mountain West teams and lost a fourth non-conference home game for the first time in outgoing coach Ricardo Patton's 11 seasons. Yet, Patton praised his team for its comeback that fell just short, saying he sees the seeds of a good team that will win its share of games if it can replicate the furious final few minutes. "We're continuing to fight the good fight," Patton said, suggesting that in the fullcourt press he may have found a style he could rely on more often to help the Buffs match up with more experienced teams. "We may have to look at that," Patton said. "We'll talk to the players about that. It takes a high level of energy to play that style. It also requires that you not rely on six or seven guys. In order to play that style, we've got to have a number of guys ready to rest guys." Smith's three-point play with 1:28 left in the first half ignited the Rams on a 17-3 run spanning halftime to turn a tie game into a 51-37 lead. Cory Lewis added 13 points for the Rams and Stephan Gilling had 12 on 4-of-5 shooting from beyond the arc, helping the Rams put to rest their incongruous streak in Boulder, where they had lost 13 in a row. "Every loss hurts," Roby said. "We cannot worry about the past. All we can worry about is what we need to improve on."
